summary: This is a sealed memorandum decision and order from the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, granting the government's application to modify a protective order from the civil defamation case Giuffre v. Maxwell. The modification allows the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP to comply with a grand jury subpoena issued as part of a federal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and others for sex trafficking of minors. The court analyzes the application under the Martindell standard and finds the government has shown extraordinary circumstances.

persons.name: Virginia L. Giuffre
persons.context: Plaintiff who sued Ghislaine Maxwell for defamation, alleging Maxwell defamed her by denying Giuffre was a victim of sex crimes by Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Defendant in the Giuffre defamation case; opposed modifications to the protective order that would allow disclosure to law enforcement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Financier and central figure in the sex trafficking investigation; his 2007 plea deal and the subsequent federal investigation are discussed.

persons.name: Robert W. Sweet
persons.context: Late judge who presided over Giuffre v. Maxwell, entered the protective order, and denied third-party motions to unseal the record.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.role: Harvard Law professor and criminal defense lawyer
persons.context: Moved to unseal a portion of the Giuffre v. Maxwell record to clear his name after Giuffre publicly alleged he perpetrated sex crimes alongside Epstein.

persons.name: Michael Cernovich
persons.context: Sought to unseal papers filed as part of Maxwell's motion for summary judgment in the Giuffre case.

persons.name: Julie Brown
persons.context: Journalist for the Miami Herald whose feature story on Epstein garnered public interest; moved post-settlement to unseal the entire Giuffre v. Maxwell record.

persons.name: Jose A. Cabranes
persons.context: Second Circuit judge who was critical during oral argument of the district court's failure to make specific findings for keeping documents sealed.

persons.name: McMahon
persons.context: Chief Judge of the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York who authored this memorandum decision and order granting the government's application.

connections.description: Plaintiff and defendant in the civil defamation lawsuit Giuffre v. Maxwell.
Maxwell is alleged to have assisted Epstein in assembling a network of underage girls for sex acts.
Giuffre alleges she was a victim of sex crimes perpetrated by Epstein.
Dershowitz sought to unseal records after Giuffre publicly accused him of perpetrating sex crimes alongside Epstein.
Boies Schiller represented Giuffre in the defamation litigation and on a pending post-settlement appeal.

events.title: Giuffre Files Defamation Lawsuit
events.description: Virginia L. Giuffre commences a civil defamation suit against Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Protective Order Entered
events.description: Judge Robert W. Sweet enters a protective order in Giuffre v. Maxwell, allowing parties to designate discovery materials as confidential.

events.title: Giuffre v. Maxwell Settled
events.description: The Giuffre Action is settled and dismissed with prejudice shortly before trial was to begin; terms remain confidential.

events.title: Federal Investigation Commenced
events.description: The Government commences an investigation into Epstein and others for sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Government Files Application
events.description: The Government files an ex parte, in camera application to Judge Sweet seeking to modify the protective order to allow Boies Schiller to comply with a grand jury subpoena.

events.title: Second Circuit Oral Argument
events.description: The Second Circuit hears argument on consolidated appeals from orders denying motions to unseal the Giuffre v. Maxwell record; the panel is critical of the district court's sealing practices.

events.title: Epstein's State Plea Deal
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleads guilty to two state prostitution charges and receives a non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ, serving 13 months in county jail.

locations: U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The court grants the government's application to modify a 2016 protective order from Giuffre v. Maxwell, allowing the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP to comply with a grand jury subpoena as part of a federal sex trafficking investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and others.
The government's investigation, commenced in late 2018, is into violations of federal sex trafficking and enticement statutes (18 U.S.C. §§ 1591, 1594(c), 2422(b)).

Judge McMahon finds that Ghislaine Maxwell's reliance on the protective order to shield materials from a grand jury subpoena was unreasonable, and that the government has demonstrated 'extraordinary circumstances' warranting modification, including significant public interest and the need for grand jury secrecy.

The decision references the controversial 2007 plea deal for Epstein, allegations of misconduct by government officials (including a then-U.S. Attorney now in the President's Cabinet), and the Miami Herald's 2018 exposé which renewed public interest.

Third parties, including Alan Dershowitz, Michael Cernovich, and the Miami Herald, had previously sought to unseal the Giuffre v. Maxwell record, but were denied by Judge Sweet; a consolidated appeal on those unsealing motions is pending before the Second Circuit.
